'Dark Age' of Tamil History?

The rule of the Kalabhras is often described as the 'Dark Age' (Ironda Kalam) in traditional Tamil historiography, as they seized power by defeating the three great dynasties of the established Sangam periodтАФthe Cholas, Cheras, and Pandyas. However, modern historians view this as a revolutionary shift, not merely a destruction.

тШ╕я╕П
Rise of Jainism and Buddhism

The Kalabhra rulers were likely followers of Buddhism or Jainism. During their reign, Brahmanical rituals declined, and the influence of Prakrit and Pali languages increased. The famous Tamil epics 'Silappadikaram' and 'Manimekalai' were likely written in this intellectual milieu. Achyuta Vikranta is the only king of this dynasty whose name is known to us from Buddhist sources.

ЁЯУЙ
Resurgence and End

At the end of the 6th century CE, Pallava king Simhavishnu and Pandya king Kadungon together defeated the Kalabhras and re-established the rule of Hindu dynasties in South India.
